content.description: A very thin crack with some juggy steps that are just far enough apart to be interesting.  Harder and more intricate than it looks!

Up the wide crack behind the pine limb, then straight up the final face. 

  You can skip the final face by squirming to the right - easier.
content.protection:
Fist- to finger-sized gear. 

  There is nowhere to set an anchor on top, so I used a small cam to set a directional on top and climbed over to set a belay in the gap above the Third Step.

content.description:
Beside the stumpy rock pillar, follow the fist crack.  You could start either left or right of the stumpy pillar. 

  (In Smith & Zimmerman, this is the "NW Corner".)
content.location: At the Northwest corner (lower left) of the Second Step.

content.description:
Sharp thin sidepulls with no feet lead to some long reaches and eventually a huge incut jug.  Smith and Zimmerman (1970) recommend leaping to the jug from the top of the First Step - not for the fainthearted! 

  Doing the leap is probably easier (technically) than climbing from the ground up.
content.location: On the Second Step, near the South edge of the West face.  The only obvious place to leap from the First Step onto the Second!

content.description: Climb lower crack to upper wide crack to top.
content.location: The next major crack directly to the right of Stump Crack

content.description: Just how difficult you make this face depends on how strictly you stay away from the West (right) Corner.
content.location: The blankest face on the First Step

content.description: Up the crack and squirm around to the right, then up to the summit.
content.location: Start at the lowest point of the First Step

content.description:
Scramble and mantle on ledges, right of the pine tree (on the North side of the East face, toward Birthday Rocks). 

  We used this as the descent route.
content.protection: There might be a piece of gear in there.
content.location: Between the First Step and the Second Step

content.description:
Visible in the boulderfield below Horse Rampart, this rib of rock is more visited by hikers scrambling than by climbers.  The three steps of Lothar's Ledges provide a rare opportunity to do a "multipitch" linkup at the Lake.  Like Turk's Head ridge, most variations are easy, but those who are really determined can find a harder linkup here. 

  Named for Lothar Kolbig, a CMCer active in the 1940s and 50s.  This area is partially documented in Smith & Zimmerman (1970).
